awd_titl_txt: CSEDI Collaborative Research: Understanding what we see in the lower mantle - mineral physics interpretation of seismic tomographic images
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth’s mantle thermal convection drives plate tectonics. It is at the origin of numerous risks for populations (e.g., earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, tsunamis). This process extracts Earth’s internal heat, notably produced by the crystallization of its core.  The core is ~3,500 km (~2,200 mi) in radius and consists mostly of iron with some nickel.  Its liquid outer shell, the outer core, generates the Earth’s magnetic field. Above the core lies the rocky mantle, a hot layer of mostly solid silicates wrapped into the planet’s crust.  The core-mantle boundary (CMB) is located ~2,900 km (1800 mi) beneath the Earth’s surface. It is a complex and critical boundary. There, heat transfer, from the core to the mantle, constrains the geodynamo and powers mantle convection. Deep patterns of mantle flow are observed by refined seismic imaging above the CMB. These structures still challenge interpretations in terms of mineralogy and thermodynamical state. Here, researchers focus on the mantle system. The multidisciplinary team of computational scientists consists of a mineral physicist, two seismologists, an applied mathematician, and a geodynamicist. It introduces innovative approaches to analyze the origin of mantle structures, including machine learning algorithm. The models are constrained with the latest mineral physics data, obtained at the extreme pressures and temperatures prevailing in Earth’s interior. Gradually, the scientists unveil the origins, compositions, and temperatures of the deep mantle structures. Outcomes of the project, i.e., state-of-the-art methods, software, and databases, will benefit the Earth Science community. The project also provides support for an early career female scientist, and training for four graduate students at Columbia University and Princeton University.

Here, the researchers use the latest shear (S-) and compressional (P-) wave models obtained by global adjoint tomography, without reference to a 1D spherical model or assumptions of correlations between compressional (VP) and shear velocity (VS) heterogeneities. They also use direct inversion, machine learning algorithms, and the latest mineral physics results on thermoelastic properties of mineral phases undergoing iron spin crossover (ISC). They pay particular attention to the effect of the ISC which disrupts the usual correlation between VS and VP heterogeneities caused by lateral temperature or composition variations. They focus on lower mantle structures, mainly plumes rooted at the CMB and possibly slabs in this region. In the process, they are formatting the mineral physics data on ISCs to make it available through two popular thermochemical and thermoelasticity software/database frameworks – BurnMan and Perple_X – that couple with geodynamic codes. With this software/data infrastructure in place, they run geodynamic simulations to understand the effect of ISC on mantle dynamics. Conversely, results of geodynamic modeling coupled to thermoelasticity data are used to synthesize tomographic images to be compared with observed mantle structures. The know-how generated by this project, i.e., methods, software, databases, and results will be made available through peer-reviewed journals and in specialized web sites, e.g., BurnMan, Perple_X, IRIS, github.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

PROJECT OUTCOMES

One of the broad goals of the CSEDI program is to advance understanding of the Deep Earth Engine, i.e., the two distinct heat transfer/producing systems connected at the complex core-mantle boundary (CMB) region. In this project, we focused on the mantle system in which refined deep seismic structures reveal mantle flow patterns or mineralogical changes.

 

Intellectual Merit – This project brought together an interdisciplinary team consisting of a materials/mineral physicist, two seismologists, an applied mathematician, and a geodynamicist, to investigate the origin of velocity structures in the Earth's lower mantle as revealed by seismic tomography. In particular, it investigated the elusive effect of iron spin crossover (ISC), i.e., the reduction of iron magnetic moment, on average mantle velocities and heterogeneities. Because the ISC occurs throughout most of the lower mantle, it does not have a sharp signature, making it challenging to pin down. Besides, the complex ISC modeling is sensitive to approximations involved in its modeling, making its effects challenging to describe.

Concrete progress was made in describing and identifying ISC effects on lower mantle velocities. Over a decade ago the ISC impact on mantle velocities and heterogeneities was predicted by ab initio calculations. Qualitatively, it consisted of a “fading” of velocity heterogeneities in P-wave models compared to S-wave models. An interdisciplinary collaboration identified the predicted effect on several tomographic models using the vote map strategy. The identified effect seemed less localized than the predicted one. The ab initio ISC modeling was repeated, upgrading the ISC solid solution modeling from ideal to non-ideal. This work showed the ISC impact on mantle velocities is more delocalized than that predicted in previous studies. Using the novel ISC modeling results, it was demonstrated that the ISC impact on 1D velocity profiles is a) to reduce P-velocities broadly with no distinct signature, and b) it is essential to describe velocity distributions in the lower mantle. Without the ISC effect, a Bayesian analysis of mantle velocities offers unrealistic temperatures and silica content. This result was obtained using the GLAD-M25 tomographic model from the Princeton collaborator, Jeroen Tromp.

We also showed how the ISC impacts the partitioning of (ferrous) iron among lower mantle phases. The partitioning effect on 1D velocity profiles is very small, but it impacts velocity heterogeneity ratios, the main signature of the origins of velocity variations in the mantle. With lateral temperature variations, this partitioning alters phase compositions that impact S- and P-velocities differently. A surprising effect was the similarity of the predicted impact of lateral temperature variations in a pyrolytic mantle in the presence of ISC and iron partitioning and the velocity variation ratios observed by numerous tomographic models down to 2,400 km depth.

This progress was reported in two articles published in Nature Communications and one nearly accepted in Geophysical Research Letters.

Other advances under this grant included the reformulation and test of a formalism for elasticity under non-hydrostatic stresses and the resolution of the phase boundary between cubic to tetragonal transition in CaSiO3-perovskite. The latter was an important step toward accurately predicting the recently observed MgSiO3-CaSiO3 solid solution.

In addition, the capability for predictions of much more complex effects has been upgraded with the introduction of machine learning potential computations of thermodynamic and thermoelastic properties, e.g., simulations of highly anharmonic effects, e.g., superionic transition, on seismic velocities.

We will use the latest shear (S-) and compressional (P-) wave models obtained by global adjoint tomography without reference to a 1D spherical model or assumptions of correlations between compressional (VP) and shear velocity (VS) heterogeneities.

Broader impacts - This project launched an important activity in geophysics on the East Coast, bringing together leading groups and creating conditions for convergence research in the framework of the CSEDI program. It also created conditions for well-rounded, interdisciplinary training of three graduate students and one postdoc. A novel approach for analyses of mantle structures was successfully used, setting new standards for analyses of mantle velocities and opening a path for mineralogical interpretations of mantle velocities. The know-how generated by this grant, i.e., methods, data, and results, were made publicly available on specialized and popular websites, e.g., Mineralscloud.org, GitHub, etc. Finally, the interdisciplinary and cross-generation interaction supported is helping to shape the future of seismic imaging analysis and interpretation.
